It is characterized by its slender, pyramidal shape and dark green, needle-like leaves that are typically arranged in spirals along the branches. The tree produces cones that are typically 5–8 centimeters long, containing winged seeds that are dispersed by wind. It thrives in cool, moist climates and is often found in cloud forests at elevations between 2,000 and 3,500 meters. Due to habitat loss and limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
